interestingcomments.content: My treatment is this: First, the light areas are coated with shoe paste from the tube. It doesn't smell strong. Not the normal shoe paste from the can! Not the seams, otherwise they will also be dark. Then with beeswax balm. But only coat the smooth areas!
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: My treatment is this: First, the light areas are coated with shoe paste from the tube. It doesn't smell strong. Not the normal shoe paste from the can! Not the seams, otherwise they will also be dark. Then with beeswax balm. But only coat the smooth areas!

interestingcomments.content: He probably means that a light bulb to the left has died, and maybe also two in the middle.
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: He probably means that a light bulb to the left has died, and maybe also two in the middle.

interestingcomments.content: 13 hours ago, kristyansen said: Thank you, noted. To relativize the statement, what would such an event be / what light conditions? The event is a youth Christian Music concert. Much of the time the only lighting on the audience is that from the stage. The room has a black, light absorbing, ceiling which makes things worse and I shoot with f2.8 zooms. Shooting the performers and those close to the stage is not a problem, but as I get further away is gets very dark.
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: 13 hours ago, kristyansen said: Thank you, noted. To relativize the statement, what would such an event be / what light conditions? interestingcomments.content: 1 hour ago, Stuart Richardson said: If you are not doing this for a living, just get a very high quality, high CRI led setup, and you will be in good shape. I've just been involved in the production of some LED lighting for a photographic set up which requires hundreds of thousands of photographs to be taken (the customer wear their dSLR's shutters out). LEDs can be problematic because many produce excess blue light. One solution is to get ones which are consistent in terms of colour temperature balance and then use mired shift filters to adjust colour temperature to whatever you want to work in for your set-up. Lee filters make sheets of such filter material). Testing has shown this to be surprisingly effective when consistency is required. One word of warning; there are various ways of achieving CIE specified light outputs and one is by mixing 'warm' and 'cold' LEDs which is OK but if and when an LED fails, they colour temperature can shift - I found out the hard way when consistency failed!

One solution is to get ones which are consistent in terms of colour temperature balance and then use mired shift filters to adjust colour temperature to whatever you want to work in for your set-up. Lee filters make sheets of such filter material). Testing has shown this to be surprisingly effective when consistency is required. One word of warning; there are various ways of achieving CIE specified light outputs and one is by mixing 'warm' and 'cold' LEDs which is OK but if and when an LED fails, they colour temperature can shift - I found out the hard way when consistency failed!

interestingcomments.content: I’m going to try and take another shot from the same position when it’s evenly lit for a comparison. The darkest central part of the image was almost into the low sun causing the shadow of the woman.
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: I’m going to try and take another shot from the same position when it’s evenly lit for a comparison. The darkest central part of the image was almost into the low sun causing the shadow of the woman.

interestingcomments.content: 24 minutes ago, otto.f said: Are you serious? Not really serious, just a plain amateur willing to learn from the pros. Welcome to Greenland, land of contrasts, where everything is either black or white (in Monochrom) as there is nothing really "grayish". M9M and Cron 28mm, no interest in this picture except that we are facing West, against the light, trust me a lot harsher in the upper right white layer of high altitude clouds than any bubble light you might have close to your books. The DR here is huge despite the appearances, there is no clipping at all and you get details from the lowest to the highest light. Now as I'm not serious at all, I accept and will learn from all whatever you'll say (you have to click on the image as the downgraded jpg does not do justice to the details). --img--  Edited January 25, 2020 by snooper
